B0009A1AS2|1.0|I've always considered these reviews to be a way to find new music: If I agreed with another reviewer about several CDs, I might try something they recommended. Reviewers like Lord Chimp and Wickerman were two of my early favorites. So when I write how this album completely sucked, I'm not being a fanboy or trasher, I'm trying to help other readers who might want to get an idea of what I like and don't like. If that helps someone out there pick up some great music - and avoid garbage like this - then my reviews are doing what they're supposed to, not gaining me more votes so that I too can be a Top x00 Reviewer.<br /><br />Why is this DT's weakest album to date? Writing. It sucks. The only tracks that catch my interest are \\"These Walls\\", \\"I Walk Beside You\\", and \\"Panic Attack.\\" \\"Never Enough\\" has moments, and \\"The Root of all Evil\\" has a great title and a brief instrumental passage before the middle break that's breathtaking, but the rest of this recording is just dreadfully dull. \\"Octavarium\\" (the song) is an outtake from Pink Floyd, as is much of \\"Sacrificed Sons;\\" not to insult PF fans, I just don't want that much of their style showing up in a DT release. And for the rest of the album, there aren't any hooks in these songs - I don't mean like in a pop formula, I mean something you find yourself humming right away or hours later. One reviewer wrote, back on 6DoIT, that there was nothing memorable about that music, and while I disagreed on that recording, I'll say it here: There's nothing memorable about this release. Except, that is, how it has so little to enjoy.<br /><br />I agree with another reviewer that these guys are overextended on side projects. Their writing has deteriorated since SfaM, and now so has their performance. And those lyrics? Dreadful. Insipid. Boring. By comparison, the lyrics on this release make Lost Horizon look like e.e. cummings. They spent months writing and arranging this CD, so why does most of the material seem so weak and undeveloped?<br /><br />Exceptions: \\"These Walls\\" sounds like an uptempo Journey number from the mid-80s; whereas songs like this normally strike me as appeasements for the record company, on this CD it's actually the best song. (That's scary.) \\"I Walk Beside You\\" is similar, very radio-friendly (even in length, at 4:29). \\"Panic Attack\\" is fast and has an echo of the work I expect from DT.<br /><br />But that's all I can find here. 75 minutes of multitrack work and  I can only appreciate about 1/4 of it. And that title track - even worse than the last Royal Hunt album. It's so damned dull it makes me angry I looked forward to another epic DT track. Even Falling Into Infinity had better writing than this, and that was my least favorite in the DT discography before this. No doubt DT fans will buy this release anyway, but I'm warning anyone willing to read about my reactions: You *might* like this recording, but don't bet on it. Fates Warning's recent \\"FWX\\" spanks this CD from start to finish.<br /><br />I give this two stars for a few decent tracks and glimpses of greatness on a couple others, but take away a star for putting out something that's overall this weak and dull. DT swings and misses by a LOT this time out...veloped? <br /> <br />Exceptions: \\"These Walls\\" sounds like an uptempo Journey number from the mid-80s; whereas songs like this normally strike me as appeasements for the record company, on this CD it's actually the best song. 076781326X|5.0|Oliver! is a lavish color muscical version of Charles Dickens' classic novel Oliver Twist.  If you haven't seen  this movie yet, you'll probably recognize some of the hit songs, including \\"Consider Yourself,\\" and \\"Where Is Love?\\"<br /><br />If you haven't read the book either, it's about a high-spirited orphan kicked out of the orphanage in Victorian England.  He escapes his new masters (undertakers!) and makes his way to London, where he's taken under the wing of Fagin (Ron Moody), a fence who employs a group of pocket-picking boys.<br /><br />The film deservedly won 6 Academy Awards, incluing Best Picture.  The actors are all perfect, especially Lester as Oliver and Wild as The Artful Dodger.  If you're the right age, you'll remember Jack Wild from the Saturday morning show H.R. Pufnstuf.  Most of the musical numbers are very entertaining, some quite spectacular, and fit in well with the story.  In my own humble opinion, this is one of the last good big musical productions filmed (though I also liked 1776 very much, a few years later).

B00030590I|4.0|After reading several reviews of this movie, I feel a bit obligated to comment on the harsher reviews.  Coming from a Chinese perspective, I watched the movie with the English subtitles, and realized that there will always be something lost in the translation.  The writing cannot be judged from the subtitles.  The script was written in something of classical Chinese (think Shakespeare vs. modern English).  As for the martial arts, unless you've seen more than just Crouching Tiger and Hidden Dragon and House of the Flying Daggers, and unless you've actually studied and learned the arts, it's difficult to pick up on the subtle differences in fighting style.  Finally, this movie is not so much about the martial arts as it is about the cinematography, music, artistry, and simplicity that is so characteristic of modern Chinese film.  This is the type of film you must see at least twice in order to fully appreciate it.  If you like foreign films and a change of pace from the mainstream Western films, you will enjoy this movie.

B0000AUHOH|5.0|I honestly can't understand the vehement angst and negativity against this film by Trekkers and average viewers alike. The tragedy about this film is that it was pre-judged by rumors in the press, thoroughly trashed. When this movie came out, I was actually publishing a magazine and my film critic quit because I wouldn't publish his review (rather than write a review, he chose to write a biased tirade about why he hated Star Trek). <br /> <br />Enough of that! The FX in this film are awful, some of them aren't even as well done as the FX in the original 1960s TV series. However, that wasn't William Shatner's fault. What happened is that there were too many leaks in the press that got back to Paramount, and they pulled the plug on FX. Luckily ILM allowed them to reuse select previous FX shots from previous films...so that, at least, you won't really notice anything amiss until about 30 minutes into the film. <br /> <br />The opening scene in this movie took my breath away. It's desolate, haunting and epic, with some of the best scoring by Jerry Goldsmith ever. This scene, which introduces Sybock, is one of the best introductions in ANY Star Trek film, or ANY film for that matter. It's that good. <br /> <br />The campfire scenes with Kirk, Spock and McCoy are some of the greatest scenes in the entire pantheon of Star Trek. There is great chemistry here, and McCoy's \\"special ingredient\\" in that chili, plus Kirk's remark about \\"an explosive combination\\" are truly delivered to evoke side-splitting laughter. Sure it's adolescent humor, but as a preamble to their subsequent philosophical discussion, it works! <br /> <br />Although much of the humor works, some of it doesn't. It works when Nimoy delivers a very subtle \\"Yes!\\" to Shatner's uninvited exclamation that \\"I could use a shower!\\" Where it doesn't work is when Scotty hits his head on the bulkhead. Again, when a bumbling Kirk, McCoy and Spock accelerate up the elevator shaft, it's more like a scene out of the Three Stooges. <br /> <br />The scene where Sybock shows them their greatest fear is underrated and perhaps the greatest acting ever presented in the sequence of Star Trek films, particularly by DeForrest Kelly. Kirk's adamant refusal to participate (e.g. \\"I need my pain!\\") is perhaps the closest that one ever comes to looking into the window of Kirk's soul, the real driving power behind Star Trek. <br /> <br />Finally, the confrontation between Kirk and \\"God\\" is the most pronounced and philosophical statement of Star Trek, a point hinted at in the TV series to be sure, but never so humorously depicted as in ST 5. To wit, Shatner's brilliant line about \\"Why does GOD need a starship?\\" With all due respect to those of faith, that is a question that any thinking person would ask about the angry war-making \\"god\\" of the Old Testament. <br /> <br />As for Jerry Goldsmith's musical score, this soundtrack is the second best soundtrack of any of the Star Trek films (his score for Star Trek: The Motion Picture is obviously the first best score). When Mr. Goldsmith died last year, we truly lost one of the Great Ones, second only to John Williams, and some might even debate that. <br /> <br />This film actually works better on TV. I attribute that to William Shatner's somewhat uncertain use of film and being more familiar with television. But, considering the fact that some scenes fully exploit the film medium on an epic scale, it is probably true that what ultimately spoiled this movie on the Big Screen is Paramount's pulling the plug on FX...virtually ruining the whole experience for Star Trek fans who by that time had become accustomed to good effects. That they were simultaneously broadcasting Next Generation with first class FX just made Paramount's decision that much more damning. Remember that this is the same studio that sat on the Star Trek franchise for almost 9 years before being prompted by the success of Star Wars to dust off their property and save Gene Goddenberry from Skid Row (typo is lovingly intentional). <br /> <br />One may be confused as to why I gave this film 5 stars in spite of the obvious flaws mentioned. The reason is that this film has an important story to tell, and tells it very well, despite the flaws. In a way, the story really begins at the campsite with Kirk, Spock and McCoy, and it ends at the campsite with Kirk, Spock and McCoy (literally), leaving a very good feeling inside. Originally I thought Star Trek V was their swan song. I'm glad it wasn't, but wouldn't have minded if it was...like a fade out into retirement... <br /> <br />This is a great Star Trek film and I never get tired of watching it!

B00082IJ08|5.0|I absolutely loved the first Gorillaz album, it is without a doubt one of my favorite albums, so of course, when I saw they were coming out with a new album, I wanted it. However, when I first heard the backstory for this new album (The Automator out, Danger Mouse in), I was a tad discouraged. Then, I read the reviews (\\"Different...much different\\"; \\"Completely new sound\\"), a was even more skeptical. However, I bought it anyway, almost out of sheer curiosity. Within 5 minutes into the CD, you know that old sound is completely out, Danger Mouse is NOT Dan The Automator and therefor will NOT sound the same, but I got into it, and it wasn't hard, not in the least. This album is as extremely accessible as the first one, and almost every song has that same \\"single worthy\\" sound to it. Yes, it is different. Yes, it tends to seem much darker. But, I believe that simply by the makeup of the band (4 cartoon characters, none of which (except 2D (Damon Albarn) having a set human counterpart portraying them), it should be expected that this album would be a completely new sound. I know that Danger Mouse only got the job because Dan and Damon had a falling out, but I truly believe that every Gorillaz album should have Albarn partnering with a new producer, it would definitely exponentially enhance my enjoyment of this band and the abstract concept of it. All in all, if you're already a Gorillaz fan, this should be a very welcomed change, and if you're not, pick up this CD, because it's really fantastic and diverse, and be sure to get the original as well. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />PS. Worth a watch at least once.

0380973634|5.0|I've had friends recommending Neil Gaiman to me for quite a while now, and for some reason, I was just never that enthused about reading anything by him. It turns out, I was really wrong. Neverwhere is the first Gaiman book I've read, and it was excellent. I can't wait to get to other novels by this guy. <br /> <br />Neverwhere is about Richard Mayhew, who is basically an unhappy loser struggling through his everyday life. That is, until he helps out a mysterious girl laying in the streets. After this, he is a loser trying to survive in the fantastical, surreal, dangerous, unbelievablely dark underworld of London. He has to encounter all sorts of maniacal enemies, including two assissins who are perhaps the most morbid I've seen in any story. Of course, he gets drawn into an impossible quest as well, and he has a few friends to accompany him through his adventures. There are some pretty old fantasy motifs here, but with Gaiman writing, everything seems original. There is certainly no excitement lacking in this compelling novel.  <br /> <br />There's also a certain depth to the novel that really adds to the effect. The novel's littered with meaningful allusions to religious stories, fairy tales, and literary works (particularly by G.K. Chesterton). It all culminates into a sort of rumination on the essentiality of imagination to enhance ordinary life and perhaps allow for transcendence.  <br /> <br />Overall, this is a really solid work. There's plenty to enjoy here and a little to think about.

B00004Y6O9|5.0|Van Halen's self-titled debut remains one of the greatest rock albums ever released as well as the band's strongest statement. This was issued at a time when the soft rock of Fleetwood Mac and the Eagles were ruling the airwaves while the hard rock of Aerosmith, Ted Nugent, and Kiss was slowly being replaced by the more radio-friendly sounds of corporate rock acts like Foreigner, Styx, and Journey. The popularity of disco also was keeping hard rock off the airwaves. Van Halen gave the genre a much needed shot in the arm with its hard partying anthems as well as their showmanship. Lead singer David Lee Roth was extremely charismatic, more so than any frontman in rock n' roll history, while Edward Van Halen would become the most accomplished and influential guitarist since Jimi Hendrix. Along with the solid drumming of Alex Van Halen and Michael Anthony's bass playing and high pitched backing vocals, they sounded like no one at the time and while literally thousands of bands have imitated them, no hard rock band has ever had the fan rapport as the original Van Halen.<br /><br />This album remains a hard rock classic as several tracks still get played regularly on AOR radio. A loud and long horn blast opens up the album and leads into \\"Runnin' With The Devil\\" with Roth's now classic charismatic showmanship and Edward's extraodinary technique. This song along with the next 3 tracks, the phenomenal guitar instrumental \\"Eruption\\", their cover of the Kinks' classic \\"You Really Got Me\\", which was better than the original, and \\"Ain't Talkin' About Love\\" remain classic rock staples over 25 years after their release. \\"I'm The One\\" is a fast paced rocker with a cool doo wop a capella vocal near its end while \\"On Fire\\" and \\"Atomic Punk\\" are relentless and continue the party atmosphere. Other great tracks include the still popular tracks \\"Jamie's Cryin\\" and \\"Feel Your Love Tonight\\" which feature great riffs and awesome harmonies. The atmospheric \\"Little Dreamer\\" and the rip roaring cover of \\"Ice Cream Man\\" are also top notch, further showcasing Roth's showmanship and Edward's sizzling guitar work. What you really get out of this album along with their next releases Van Halen II and Women and Children First is a band who loved what they did and didn't take things too seriously. While they would continue to make strong albums after this, the innocence that made them so appealing was lost. And once Roth left the fold in 1985, the magic was truly gone despite their continued chart success. However, Van Halen's debut remains a timeless album that never fails to entertain and should be a part of every music fan's collection.ring cover of \\"Ice Cream Man\\" are also top notch, further showcasing Roth's showmanship and Edward's sizzling guitar work. What you really get out of this album along with their next releases Van Halen II and Women and Children First is a band who loved what they did and didn't take things too seriously. While they would continue to make strong albums after this, the innocence that made them so appealing was lost. And once Roth left the fold in 1985, the magic was truly gone despite their continued chart success. However, Van Halen's debut remains a timeless album that never fails to entertain and should be a part of every music fan's collection.
B00000DG1R|5.0|When my 'Decade' CD from 1989 eventually gave up the ghost, I went looking for a replacement; I went one better and bought this. B0000508U6|4.0|Coldplay's Parachutes is their debut release and remains their most subdued effort. While future albums A Rush of Blood to the Head and X&Y would mix songs of both beauty and sadness throughout, Parachutes is more somber than joyous. The album starts with \\"Don't Panic\\", a solid mid-tempo track which introduces the music world to Chris Martin's very distinctive voice, one that draws equally from both soft spoken emotion and a fairly high falsetto. The bass work of Guy Berryman is more prevalent here than on their other albums and is a highlight of the moody tracks \\"Spies\\" and \\"High Speed.\\" Jon Buckland's guitar work is solid throughout, whether it's on the hard rock of the hit single \\"Yellow\\", the memorable ringing lines of \\"Everything's Not Lost\\", or his acoustic work on \\"We Never Change\\" and \\"Sparks.\\" While the previously mentioned \\"Yellow\\" is the well known track, it's actually one of the weaker cuts, feeling like a last minute addition to get airplay. The best songs here are \\"Trouble\\", a melancholy piano ballad with a chorus that reminds you of Pink Floyd in both sound and feel, and the rocker \\"Shiver\\", a hopeful track with great lyrics, awesome guitar work from Buckland, and a passionate vocal performance from Martin. The aforementioned \\"Sparks\\", \\"We Never Change\\" and \\"Spies\\" are great tracks as well. So why not 5 stars? Well, compared to their later efforts, it's pretty tame and doesn't contain those albums' diversity, particularly on the second half. However, this is better than most of the music out now and is definitely worth the purchase.
0312995423|1.0|I sure hope that the technological errors in Digital Fortress are not a reflection of Dan Brown's research abilities. Some of the errors were so glaring that I wanted to throw the book out the window. But I'm used to seeing similar problems in movies, so I thought I'd go along for the ride. But here are some of the biggest blunders:<br /><br />1. The NSA commander wants to patch some encryption code with a backdoor and replace the version on the web with his own. This won't work because no one in security trusts code that doesn't match a hash from the original author. This is how code is authenticated. Is standard practice. His patch would cause the hash to fail. Also, everyone else who really wanted the encryption code already downloaded the original version - just like the commander did. They aren't going to get a new one. What BS!<br /><br />2. A $2B computer designed to crack codes would have separate code and data spaces in memory. It would be impossible for an encrypted communication to infect the host with a \\"virus\\" or \\"worm\\" because the communication would only be in the data memory space. Just because Microsoft doesn't use secure systems architecture doesn't mean the NSA wouldn't! More BS!<br /><br />3. No one hand-solders CPUs even if they are in a $2B computer... And especially if there are 3 million of them! It's called \\"wave soldering\\"... Brown obviously connects hand-soldering with extreme technical know-how because he later has the head computer geek hand-soldering a chip inside a running mainframe. Can you say BS!<br /><br />4. When a computer overheats, the temperature tolerance of the CPU may be exceeded by a few degrees, especially in highly sensitive, high-performance equipment. Silicon, by it's nature, changes in resistance dramatically when the temperature exceeds operational parameters. If it gets too hot, the circuits slow down. There's no way a \\"virus\\" or a \\"worm\\" could cause anything other than a system shutdown due to temperature variations - and a really sensitive system would automatically shutdown when the temperate range was exceeded by a few degrees. There's no way in heck the system would continue to run until it reached a temperature where the silicon would explode! Come on - I thought Brown did at least some research.<br /><br />If anything, these errors make me think that Lewis Perdue actually did Brown's research for Da Vinci Code - but not willingly...automatically shutdown when the temperate range was exceeded by a few degrees. There's no way in heck the system would continue to run until it reached a temperature where the silicon would explode! Come on - I thought Brown did at least some research.  If anything, these errors make me think that Lewis Perdue actually did Brown's research for Da Vinci Code - but not willingly...

B0006L16N8|5.0|You don't have to lecture to me about the value of reinvention. I think Kid A by Radiohead is the most important record in modern music, PERIOD! The same with X & Y. If it works, don't knock it. X & Y isn't the most original album, but it's a powerhouse work. I'm so glad they did this, verses the possibility of reinventing themselves, and failing misreably. B0009HLDFU|3.0|While this is a big step up from their last cd, the Foo Fighters are definitely not back to the level at which their first 3 albums were. The tunefulness is lacking; some of the riffs are exactly the same as riffs from previous albums; and even though there are 20 songs spanning 2 discs, there's a distinct lack of ambition. I'm rarely the type to dissect double albums to say \\"boy wouldn't it be great if only the best ten or twelve had been selected to make one great album,\\" but this is definitely a case for it. A mix between the best of the first and second discs could have created a rock-solid cd, copy-protection or not. (By the way, the same strategy of rock disc/softer disc was used a few years ago by Paul Westerberg on his latterday masterpiece \\"Stereo/Mono\\" to much greater effect.)<br /><br />So, my conclusion about this album is that it's good but not great, interesting in spots, inspired in spots. After 3 great albums and one semi-clunker, I was left wondering what would come next for this band. In Your Honor doesn't really answer one way or another, so it seems it could go either way. Let's hope for a more focused effort next time out.

B00008G9JM|5.0|Jeez, how do you tackle a 500 pound gorilla?  Very carefully, with eyes (yea, the third one too) and ears wide open!  This gorilla has an eye-patch, wears a tutu and wants to discuss Voltaire, Nietzsche and Kant (with a nice bottle of scotch and a cigar).  He's an impressive beast, but has a scary asymmetry and might lull you into a menacing corner of Tulldom that might jade one forever.  I have always been pretty content with the tribe of plain old monkeys (of the usual TULL songs).  The times I CRANK IT UP and play guitar, bass or drums to it, the energy of the album bowls me over and it can do no wrong.  It's exciting steppin' out with the gorillas.  This could almost be described as the \\"musician's album\\" of the line-up - musicians will certainly want to study the great ideas explored here.  There are brilliant and powerful passages throughout that equal Thick easily, but somehow (at other times) it can seem kind of flat in a melodic/harmonic sense, I guess gorillas don't sing quite as sweetly.  I consider myself to be a prog old-timer and have explored the genre substantially, and this is one of the masterpieces for sure (listening to the first few minutes could tell you that), but it has a strange brew of ideas that sometimes don't gel totally.  I'll admit that I've always found the Hare story to be a bit of an intrusion and too long...although somewhat charming in its own right (I have kids - they should have made a children's prog album!).  The storyline has never taken my mind's eye to the great song-writing landscapes of many other great TULL songs (that's the tutu on the gorilla).  My weakness for this album is all about powerful, and I mean POWERFUL playing of this great line-up of TULL.  Man, are they smokin' in spots (eye-patch)!<br /><br />This is certainly a treasured piece of the intricate TULL puzzle...figure it out if you can (Kant and Nietzsche are puzzling as well).  Otherwise, just bang your drums or hammer your guitar until your tendons snap.  Nice work-out tape!  The real BENEFIT of being a TULL fan is the incredible diversity and uniqueness of each album.  They are all great in their own way.  In this tribe, gorillas and the more diminutive breeds live in musical harmony.  Thank you TULL for adding so much to the musical fabric (and rockin' my obviously devolved world - us neanderTULLs can't get enough). I also think Ian had one hell of a concept here ... this could have made an excellent stage production - it is very clever and well-crafted (and just sounds plain old TRIPPY!). All members are near the top of their game it appears to me, and I know all of these albums like the back of my hand.<br /><br />Look where this sits in the stretch ... smack in the middle of TULL paradise. Shame on many of you (TULL fans) for dismissing this album after only a few listens, sometimes the stealth albums come back and 'knock you upside the head' with their brilliance later when they've matured in your subconscious (one of the most melodic TULL albums).<br /><br />Listen to some of the songs like Chequered Flag, Deadbeat, Too Old and Big Dipper - melodic, shimmering, beautiful, poetic and really spacy! Salamander would give John Renbourn a run for his money, that's a snazzy song my friends! Bad Eyed & Loveless, Pied Piper and From a Deadbeat to an Old Greaser sound so cool with their slowed-down lilting psychedelic (reverb soaked) charm...<br /><br />OH YEAH, THIS IS THE REAL DEAL FOR LOVERS OF CLASSIC TULL! If you love Minstrel especially, you should appreciate this. No, you're never too old to rock 'n' roll if you're too young to die. I know the real world keeps many people too busy, but take the time to really listen to good music...CRANK IT UP - ENJOY!!<br /><br />P.S. Small Cigar is also a nice addition, funny song - and I guess it's not (or is it?) about the rolled non-tobacco type. Nice remastering job (and packaging) with lyrics, good track notes and comments by Ian (just under 50 minutes - sniff).but take the time to really listen to good music...CRANK IT UP - ENJOY!!     P.S. Small Cigar is also a nice addition, funny song - and I guess it's not (or is it?) about the rolled non-tobacco type. Nice remastering job (and packaging) with lyrics, good track notes and comments by Ian (just under 50 minutes - sniff).

This will enhance the credibility of the president as election is round the corner.<br /><br />Everything goes as planned. The meteor is dicovered and its age confirmed. B00005YU1O|4.0|I have been teaching a Basic Design class for over 5 years and Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs has been a part of my curriculum to the present.  Why am I mentioning this Disney classic?  Because there are correlations between Waking Life and the infamous, \\"Sleeping Death\\" in Snow White, missed by most if not all of these reviews. <br />I think everyone is anxious about the issues concerning death through faith and philosophy and they miss some crucial points from Waking Life. <br />The first, the medium itself.  Snow White was Disneys' first full length feature animation film and it used a film/animation process called Rotoscope.  This is where the realistic characters like Snow White, the Prince and Evil Princess were all modeled after live action footage.  This is also used in Waking Life through a more contemporary digital process created by the animator while attending the MIT media lab.  So the medium is the first correlation.   <br />Next, the message (if you will):  Snow White is full of issues concerning gender roles, sexuality, aging, work ethic, purity, faith, death and so forth.  These are deep and troubling aspects of life generalized or simplified in Snow White. Disney's contrivence from the sexually and socially charged Brothers' Grimm fairytale creates more disturbing ideals concerning conformity to social norms (i.e. gender roles; women home/men at work; beauty/vanity). Also,notice the number of writers who worked on the film in the closing credits.  This alone raises some speculation on these issues and how to draw [sic] these ideals up.   <br />Why does this matter?  Look and discover all the loose ends in Waking Life.  Mysteries revealing only more mysteries.  Nothing is pinned down and this flows througout the neo-phychedellic animation like levels of moving water.  Life can't be held and understood. And here in Waking Life, death is sought along with life.  \\"Sleeping Death\\" in Snow White is somehow an avoidance of life's terms, the end.  Not really dying, just sleeping and awaiting the \\"...life, happily everafter\\".  Where at least Waking Life confronts death as an awakening and a continuum of learning like life can be.  Anyone who sees this movie and barks 'psuedo-philosophy' is attempting to pin life and death down.  Waking Life is just a movement through space in an aesethically pleasing way. <br />Believe me, these questions and philosophical meanderings are by far more enertaining than the fill and fluff of countless long songs in Snow White.  Count the length of songs vs. story/action in Snow White, it's unbearable at times. <br />I give this movie  Four Stars, understanding how these countless questions can burden ones' mind.  However, the animation gets Five.  Oh, believe me, I know there is more to write and even discuss between these two animation classics.

B00001NFMF|4.0|Anyone familiar with the signature Tull sound is in for a surprise with this album. \\"This Was\\" occupies a unique place in the band's discography, as it is their only true blues-rock record. Much of this is to be credited to the influence of Mick Abrahams (guitar), who always leaned towards this style. But it's also true that there were dozens of British bands exploring the blues field at that time. Your attitude towards blues-rock perfectly defines whether you'll like this album, or not, as the material itself is quite good. <br /> <br />I find it surprising that the level of the songs on \\"This Was\\" is so unexpectedly high for a debut album of a band that was almost constantly shifting its line-up in its early phase of existence. There are many impressive tracks on the album, but I'd like to mention \\"Some Day The Sun Won't Shine For You\\", and \\"It's Breaking Me Up\\". An instrumental \\"Serenade To A Cuckoo\\" is noteworthy, as it was written by a jazz flutist Roland Kirk, whose style of playing influenced Ian Anderson much. It's also known as the first flute tune that Anderson learned to play. \\"This Was\\" gives Ian's soon-to-be-famous flute a lot of playing time, while Mick Abrahams' bluesy guitar provides a good counterpoint. You can feel these two men rivalling for the band leadership, the battle that Ian won, and Mick lost, and left Tull for a band called Blodwyn Pig. His departure was mainly the reason for Jethro Tull losing their bluesy edge and leaning more towards folk music on future albums. <br /> <br />Surely, the album is not without its flaws, the completely unnecessary drum solo on \\"Dharma For One\\" being the most painful of them. But to any Tull fan this album comes highly recommended, as it shows the little known nature of this band, the one that doesn't show itself on any other JT album. And the sound quality is surprisingly good, too!

B0009A1AS2|5.0|I have been an avid Dream Theater fan for many years, however I was always a little disappointed with the lack of 'feeling' in their music. 6305558167|5.0|As many reviewers have commented Excalibur stands out as the best movie based on the Arthurian legend. This movie traces the whole arc of the myth from the origin of Excalibur, Merlin, the circumstances of the birth of Arthur to him becoming King, Camelot and the Round Table, the betrayal of Arthur by Lancelot and Guenevere, the downfall of Camelot, Morgana and Mordred, the quest of the Grail, to the final climatic battle scene and the returning of Excalibur to the Lady of the Lake. Director John Boorman and the adaptation of the Thomas Malory tale by Rospo Pallenberg embraces the myth instead of trying to impose modern sensibilities on the story. This is in contrast to the recent Hollywood movies that use mythical tales or history, for example Stone's Alexander, Troy, Kingdom of Heaven, and the recent Arthur movies, Fuqua's Arthur, or Last Knight, which have fallen flat because of the director and/or screen writer instead of treating the subject and tale with respect imposed a modern lens on the story or eliminated the mysticism and spirituality from the tales. There are many fascinating aspects to this movie. I thought how the movie wonderfully portrays a world in flux between pantheistism and Christianity. You have the pagan aspects with Merlin, Morgana, the magical elements of the movie, the allegory of the Dragon, and the linkage between the spiritual state of King Arthur and the prosperity of the kingdom. When Arthur is first King the land is full of life and prosperous but after he falls into despair the land becomes barren with clouded skies, leaveless trees and death is everywhere. After Arthur drinks from the Holy Grail and his soul is replished by the grace of God you see when he rides out with the remnants of his knights the land is becoming alive again with trees flowering under a sunny sky. You also a world changing with the rise of Christianity. You see priests and monks, characters wearing crucifixes, the spartan chapel at Camelot, Guenevere becoming a nun and entering a convent after her adultery, the quest for the Grail, and Lancelot becoming a monk like character in the wilderness. Merlin himself alludes to this changing world talking about the One God replacing the many gods and his age is ending and the age of man beginning. One sees this theme repeated in Tolkein's Lord of the Ring trilogy with the age of the pantheistic magical elves ending being replaced by the age of men. <br />   The movie does not shy away from the moral play of the legend. Acts of lust for power and sex end in tragedy for Uther, Lancelot and Guenevere, and even Morgana. One sees how the power of despair overcomes Arthur and almost destroys the soul of Perceval who is able to discover the Grail when he keeps hope and faith alive and only when he is able to release his bonds to the material world. (When watching the scene where he falls into the river, takes off his armor and is only wearing a white undergarment I was thinking this is an analogy of baptism and spiritual renewal.) One sees the power of forgiveness and love and how this act enables Arthur to defeat evil incarnate in Moored. Arthur does not kill Lancelot and Guenevere when he had a chance thus saving Excalibur. This act of mercy plays a key role later in the movie because Guenevere keeps Excalibur and gives it to Arthur when he comes to her to offer her his forgiveness and Lancelot comes back for the final battle to help save the kingdom from evil and he is reconciled with Arthur. <br />   The movie does not shy away from realism too. The plated armor the knights wear were not used until the late medieval period although this adds to the mythical world Boorman created one sees the brutish nature of hand to hand combat with knights struggling to fight in the mud and muck. This is not some glamorized form of medieval warfare. <br />   From an acting viewpoint Nicol Williamson as Merlin and Helen Mirren as Morgana steal the show. Nicol Williamson fully embraces Merlin inhis humor, wisdom, foreboding, manipulating events, and sad realization that the fallen nature of man will always thwart his best efforts. Helen Mirren is diabolical good as Morgana embracing her sexuality, and lust for power and revenge. Nigel Terry as Arthur gives a good performance first as a simple squire confused about what to do when he discovers his true heritage, to a King trying to rule a kingdom with wisdom while trying to be a husband, to his despair and spiritual renewal. As commented before one sees now famous actors in early roles from Gabriel Byrne playing Arthur's father Uther in the opening scenes, to Patrick Stewart as Leondegrance in full armor and yielding a battle axe Grimli from LOTR would be proud of to, to Liam Nesson as the Round Table knight Gawain. <br />   The music is another strong point for this movie.  In a stroke of genius, John Boorman instead of wanting an original score extensively uses Wagner and Carl Oraff's `Carmina Burana' before it was fashionable. It seems so appropriate since Wagner's music is for operas that explore similar myths to the Arthurian legend or are itself based on the myth, Parsifal. <br />   The movie is rated R because of nudity and sexual scenes, and scenes of combat with blood and limbs being chopped off. <br />  This movie is the best mythical tale on a screen until the Lord of the Rings trilogy. <br />
B00008OE4W|4.0|A great film that captures the start of the dot com period of history. With a twist to the story that pays homage to some of the urban legends that are running around. Altogether a good story with a cast that knows what they are doing and are enjoying themselves while doing it.
B00082IJ08|4.0|This being the gorillaz second major release, it was a given that I would pick it up. A fan of Blur and the original Gorillaz album, I expected to be treated to the same blissful pop ear-candy that was the first Gorillaz album. I wasn't. I do not see this album becoming as popular as the previous one. However, the more I listen to it, the more I appreciate it for what Damon Albarn wants it to be (or.. what the Gorillaz intend it to be). A complete mix of many styles and yet still catchy in its own peculiar way. Taking a cue from the first album, its neat to imagine all the various guest rappers being channeled through Russell.. The only drawbacks to me are the lack of the three other original 'members' of the band.. Deltron, Dan the A. and Miho Hatori (sp?) do not seem to have returned. This at once lets the band be seen as more of its own separate identity (or it makes it seem as solely belonging to Damon Albarn.. a plus or minus as you may decide for yourself.) The addition of Danger Mouse is nice.. I'm sure his skills are evident in the loops and beats throughout the album but I'm not familiar with the Grey album. This is more then just an album of music tracks. It's a neat little continuation of a musical experiment and deserving of being listened to as an album.  <br />Aside from the techno DJ influences, guest rapping and pondering voice of Albarn.. there's so many other musical highlights on the album.. gospel choirs, violins, piano solos.. in fact the only major drawback  is that annoying \\"BreeOW!\\" on track 9 (November Has Come) and I will only forgive it since I imagine its Noodle yelping along to the music..  <br /> <br />Highlights: Dennis Hopper's narration on track 13. How is that for cool? And for some reason the beat on Kids with Guns is one of my favorites.

B00005JLRT|3.0|Part of me really wants to be nice to \\"Star Trek: Nemesis.\\"  After all, it could very well be the last Star Trek film ever.  However, this film has such major problems that it can't be viewed as more than a mediocre Trek entry.<br /><br />The entire first hour of this film is borderline boring.  Star Trek film usually take a while to get going, but \\"Nemesis\\" takes this to absurd lengths.  Other than a shocking opening scene, very little happens in the film's first act, with the exception of the car chase (more on that atrocity later).  With the exception of Stewart, none of the actors here stand out.  The Trek regulars are obviously trying because they knew this would be their last gyst, but they still come off as dull, and Worf is turned into a comic sidekick.<br /><br />The guest list in \\"First Contact\\" and \\"Insurrection\\" was impressive- Alfre Woodard, James Cromwell, Alice Kridge, F. Murray Abraham, Anthony Zerbe, Donna Muprhey.  Here, we're instead stuck with Tom Hardy and Dina Meyer.  Hardy obviously tries as the villain Shinzon, but he's hampered by the fact that he bears no resemblance to Picard (who's supposedly his doppleganger) and that he spends half the film trying to imitate Khan (Trek villains really need to stop that; no one will ever again match Khan).  Meyer shows no energy whatsoever.  The only good guest star is Ron Perlman, but he's criminally underused (see \\"Hellboy\\" for what this guy is capable of).<br /><br />The greatest flaw of \\"Nemesis\\" is that it is, at heart, a dumb action film.  This is Star Trek Lite.  I suppose it was inevitable.  Star Trek films have always been about ideas over action, but in the age of loud explosions and mindless thrills (after all, Jerry Bruckheimer is now one of the most successful producers ever), this formula has come to look like a dinosaur to mainstream audiences.  The Star Trek producers would inevitably try to make the franchise appeal to mainstream audiences again by sacrificing Star Trek's very soul, while at the same time trying to keep hardcore fans on board.  The result is a film that is still too talky and slow for mainstream audiences, but is dumbed down just enough to piss off Trekkies.<br /><br />Case in point is the \\"car chase\\" early on in the film.  It has little importance to the plot, and it's downright stupid.  Of course, it is competently done, but you never get the feeling when you're watching it that this is a Star Trek film- it could have been pulled out of any Bruckheimer picture.  I'm not even getting into the flaws that geeks spot, such as how the Enterprise crew in this sequence basically ignores all Federation protocol.<br /><br />If it sounds like I'm roasting \\"Nemesis,\\" let me say that it's not a BAD movie in the sense that \\"The Final Frontier\\" was.  Indeed, \\"Nemesis\\" can be lauded for doing one thing right- saving its best for last.  All of its memorable moments happen in the final 40 minutes, which contain such impressive and tense space battles that you almost forget everything stupid that's happened before.  Almost, that is.<br /><br />I gave both \\"Insurrection\\" and \\"Nemesis\\" three stars, but \\"Insurrection\\" is the superior film, if only because it tries to stick to the Star Trek formula.  \\"Nemesis\\" is a misguided attempt to reshape Star Trek into an action franchise, and it simply doesn't fit.  Star Trek is supposed to be about more than space battles and explosions.  I don't know if there will ever be another Trek film, but \\"Nemesis\\" shows what happens to good franchises when their producers decide that they must be dumbed down for mainstream tastes (see the 1989-1997 \\"Batman\\" franchise for another example of this).  It is an enjoyable film with some great action scenes, but it has little else.  And Star Trek deserves better.

Also this is a great movie for kids. In fact I think the target audience is kids as there are no adult-jokes that come to mind at all.

B0009PVZWI|3.0|Foo Fighters \\"In your honor\\"    After listening to DISC ONE it is safe to say that \\"The Colour and The Shape\\" is still easily the Foo Fighters finest moment. After watching the bonus DVD it is easy to appreciate the effort that has gone into the \\"rock\\" CD, however in my opinion the band has tried too hard and numerous songs on the album are forced with the end result being a pedestrian release devoid of any major highlights.  In racing terms this would be a one-paced horse that fails to accelerate in a distance event. The Foo Fighters need to go back to basics, let the lyrics and music flow and not try to force the issue. Many football teams make the mistake of trying to score on every play and the Foo Fighters are guilty of this throughout this album.     Whilst it is certainly not a complete dud and will likely create a few radio hits I doubt it will ultimately fulfil Dave's wish of being the album fans will remember in 20 years time. Whether or not the Foo Fighters have an album in them to rival \\"The Colour and The Shape\\" remains to be seen, however unless they go back to their roots it may be a pipedream.    The album is far from being overproduced or cheesy it is just that on the whole some songs simply don't work. I really wanted to like this album (TCATS is currently in my 3-disc player) but I am only prepared to give it a 6.5/10    DISC TWO    I must say that DISC TWO made the whole experience worthwhile. Certainly a risk for a rock group to produce an album of acoustic numbers, however the experiment works and reminds us of what could have been on DISC ONE. There are some similarities with Nirvana and The Eagles to be found here and I am interested in the background of some of the songs and the motives behind them. Dave's vocals are not stretched, the songs provide a welcome dose of emotion and this DISC would be well suited to following one of Dido's efforts at a dinner party.  7.5/10      OVERALL: On the whole \\"In Your Honour\\" is likely to appease many fans but disappoint its fair share also despite the acoustic disc providing some hope for future Foo Fighters releases. It will be interesting to see where the band goes next, however trying to produce another TCATS could be a step back in the right direction. The album and the concept no doubt will sell quite well, and reviews will vary depending on personal tastes, however on the whole this release is a letdown.    ***          In your Honor    Yes we can hear you screaming Dave. There is an immense build of pressure and expectation in this song, and when the pressure valve should be released there is nothing left.     No Way Back    This is what the Foo's do best, straight up and down rocker that is a likely grower. Up beat with some ferocious guitar work this song gives the album some much-needed momentum.    Best Of You  Complex, varied, powerful and at time it comes across as being a little forced. Definitely a grower and a major hit, however this song just felt overdone, somewhat repetitive and in need of a little more respite to take it to the next level. Nevertheless will be a feature when the Foo's unleash their best of.    DOA    This is a great song and one of the very few highlights on DISC ONE. The band seems to have let go on this occasion and not tried to force the issue on the listener. Would not have been out of place on TINLTL and is more towards the mainstream than some of the other tracks on the album. Great drums and solid guitar work are a standout here.    HELL    After another heavy opening this song threatens to lighten up, but quickly swings back to a ferocious mix of vocals and loud guitar. Another song where the build up doesn't seem to take the song anywhere.    THE LAST SONG    Catchy intro, great drums, powerful yet restrained vocals lead into a song more reminiscent of the \\"Colour and the shape\\". Solid, stock standard Foo's song that is a potential grower.    FREE ME    The intro brings back memories of the Foo's (Dave's) debut. Although the song certainly has its moments it never reaches any great heights and is unlikely to go much further than this album    RESOLVE    A far more laidback tune that doesn't take it itself too seriously and benefits as a result. Solid guitar, drums and vocals throughout but only an average song by the Foo's standard in the end.    THE DEEPEST BLUES ARE BLACK    After a gentle bluesy intro the song launches itself with some powerful guitars and vocals that are fairly well contained in this song. Has some interesting moments musically but like most of this album fails to reach any great heights and hard to see it going anywhere.    END OVER END    This song has the right formula, right structure and is largely free of Dave's shouting and would be right at home on TINLTL.  After establishing a very solid platform to create something special to finish off disc one this one falls short of the mark.    DISC TWO    STILL    Flowing on from the rock album this song initially was relief before boredom set in. Just does not go anywhere.    WHAT IF I DO?    This song has a lot going for it and would have been welcomed on the rock album albeit after an injection of power. There is enough here to keep the listener more than a little interested.    MIRACLE    Memories of the old \\"Foo Fighters\\" are starting to flood back. Dave's vocals on this one are first class and again the structure would have been appreciated on the first CD.    ANOTHER ROUND    Another strong performance vocally from Dave but this is nothing more than a simple song. Could well be used at some pubs and clubs to signal final drinks although it is unlikely to knock Khe Sanh off its pedestal in Australia.    FRIEND OF A FRIEND    This one has a \\"Nirvana\\" feel about it, similar to \\"Something in the Way\\" and even has \\"Nevermind\\" in the lyrics. Interesting on a number of fronts and interesting to see where this song came from and the ideas behind it.    OVER AND OUT    Nice acoustic guitar to start proceedings, solid vocals and after starting to lose its way towards the middle Dave brings it back from the brink with some excellent and heartfelt vocals.  At last two pretty good songs back to back.    ON THE MEND    The acoustic album is now easily over the line in terms of preference. This is far from a being a great song but it flows on nicely from some excellent songs down the order.    VIRGINIA MOON    Experimental, laidback, a little gimmicky and doesn't really go anywhere but certainly was an interesting experience.    COLD DAY IN THE SUN    The heaviest acoustic song on the disc and in places sounds very similar to The Eagles with the guitar, vocal work and general vibe. On the whole a pretty good song for Disc 2 and hit material if dressed up for the disappointing first disc.    RAZOR    Some interesting guitar work here and Dave's form on the acoustic CD continues with a solid vocal delivery. Standard fare in light of other songs on DISC TWO.

This song would be played over and over again as I'd drive to and from work.  Great tune. <br /> <br />My personal favourite though, is Amsterdam.  A very personal, and moving song. Which is all good, except for that's completely different than what I expected from them.   <br /> <br />Buy A Rush of Blood to the Head, than Parachutes, and then X&Y.. the first two discs are far superior to their 3rd.
B0002PZVHK|5.0|Brian Eno's \\"On Land\\", recorded over the course of four years, is a meditation on places.  Whereas previous albums were intended to serve as soundtracks to different events (\\"Music for Films\\", \\"Music For Airports\\"), were fusions of someone else's idiom into his own (\\"The Plateaux of Mirrors\\", \\"No Pussyfooting\\"), or were Eno simply looking for his own footing in experimentation with often amazing results (\\"Another Green World\\", \\"Discreet Music\\"), this one seeks a more specific goal, to bring the listener into Eno's experience of a location. <br /> <br />What is remarkable is that the record succeeds so well in such an abstract goal.  Eno is able to raise the sort of spirits he is trying to.  Admittedly, it seems like he's not entirely happy with these places (or times?), there's a sense of foreboding, longing, and nearly hopelessness on the strongest cuts on the record (\\"The Lost Day\\", \\"Shadow\\").  The exception to this is the oddly optimistic and brilliant \\"Unfamiliar Wind\\", which evokes a sense of expectation and happiness.  In all, this is really one of the better records in his catalog.  Recommended.

Well this demonstrates perfectly the Seattle sound. It features two of my favorite Pearl Jam songs that weren't released. It has Mother Love Bone. It really shows the music as it was. I advise you to pick this up.
B0002PZVH0|4.0|Brian Eno's \\"Music For Airports\\" is a further realization of his ambient concept, first realized on \\"Discreet Music\\".  The concept again is similar, simple lines of varying lengths are played in loops, allowing them to interact in various ways.  The results are often times remarkable.  For music intended to be background material, this work can grab your attention. <br /> <br />The opening movement, and probably the best on the release, is a good example of Eno's idiom-- two or three extended loops of simple piano and electric piano intertwine.  The results are absolutely stunning as the music has a delicate and gentle quality to it.  While the rest of the record isn't nearly as good as this piece (one piece is a vocal-only loop piece, one is vocal-and-piano, and the closer is pure synthesizer), it is all quite good. <br /> <br />\\"Music For Airports\\" is an engaging and interesting record, well worth investigation for anyone interested in ambient music.  I prefer Eno's \\"Discreet Music\\" for early ambient material, but this is a superb record.  Recommended.

B00003CX8N|5.0|Released in 1987, this film is based on a book by the same name by New York author Helene Hanff of her correspondence with a bookseller Frank Doel (Anthony Hopkins)of Marks & Co. at 84, Charing Cross Road, London. Hanff (Anne Bancroft) and Doel develop a friendship, beginning in 1949, when she orders her first book from the London company, that lasts for 20 years. The brash Hanff and the gentle Doel carry on a correspondence that deepens into something both beautiful and bittersweet since they never meet. Hanff gets sidetracked in her planned visits to London because of recurring unforeseen expenses. Dental work and new apartments get in her way.<br /><br />The movie is not for everyone, just those who love books. It will easily become one of your favorite movies. You can practically smell the wonderful \\"antiquarian\\" books in the London shop where Doel works. (Hanff opines early on that the word \\"antiquarian\\" scares her since it often denotes expensive books.)<br /><br />Brancroft and Hopkins are joined by Judy Dench who plays Hopkins' wife. All three actors give excellent performances. It's good to know that Ms. Bancroft can be remembered for other fine roles besides her portrayal of an older married woman (Mrs. Robinson) who seduces a younger man in THE GRADUATE.<br /><br />There are many interesting touches here about current events-- actual television footage from Queen Elizabeth's Coronation, references to the Civil Rights Movement-- Hanff at one point  gets arrested when she gets in the middle of a student demonstration-- and the rationing of meat in England after World War II.<br /><br />The beauty of this film is that when you mention it to another booklover, they light up. You know if you aren't already, that you and they will become friends.
B0007XT87G|4.0|Review by Tyler Wagnon: <br /> <br />Porcupine Tree plays melodic, progressive rock with a bit of a lean to the metal side here and there. They have always been sort of hit or miss, not so much from album to album, but more from song to song, even riff to riff. However, when they hit, they really f-ing hit. Particularly in their more somber tracks, for example, \\"Trains\\" from their In Absentia album is simply one of the most gorgeous songs of the prog rock genre. <br /> <br />Deadwing, the follow up to In Absentia, pretty much picks up where the other left off. They continue to forge a pretty unique path with their infectious melodies, and relentless experimentation. The vocals and riffs on \\"Shallow\\" and \\"Open Car\\" have a distinct Tool/Maynard feel to them, which is some of their best aggressive tracks to date. \\"Lazarus\\" is a somber tune rife with piano, acoustic guitar, and a stringed arrangement, complimented by Steven Wilson's beautiful singing. \\"Arriving Somewhere (But Not Here)\\" starts out somber enough, but at around 6 minutes rips into a nice heavy riff and before it's all said and done, the song reverts into a guitar solo backed by light percussion and ambient noise. <br /> <br />On an interesting side note, Mikael Akerfeldt of Opeth helps out with harmonizing vocals on the title track, \\"Lazarus\\", and \\"Arriving Somewhere\\" as well as playing the above mentioned solo on \\"Arriving Somewhere\\". <br /> <br />As with past releases, the somber vocals and harmonies are superb, and sometimes the more forceful singing loses me a bit, but they pull it off better on this release than in the past. If you liked them before, you will like them again. If you are a little leery of the \\"progressive\\" nature of the music, give it a try. I hate 90% of any music considered progressive, but Porcupine Tree are way better than most.

0393317552|5.0|If you have not heard of the theories expounded in this book, it will be a real eye-opener for any reader. Contained within the text is really the mechanism that decided which civilizations were to be successful and which were to remain in the early stages of development.  The author does an excellent job explaining in clear easy to understand terms the reasons for Western European civilization's dominance.  A dominance to the point of colonizing the remaining lesser developed regions of the Earth. <br />In a nutshell the Author's point is that every primitive culture has already leveraged and maximized any advantage the environment has offered.  Western Europe had inherited and developed the gifts bequeathed from Mesopotamian civilizations including, domesticated animals, some optimal grain crops, some fiber crops.  With this springboard combined with the discovery of steel making and by happenstance a society exposed and partially immune to the affects of the major diseases affecting urban populations, it became an invincible combination to subjugate and rule major portions of the globe.  Areas of the world that did not benefit from having all the right ingredients or stepping stones to capitalize their environment and take them to the next level were subdued.  An example would be a culture without a suitable pack animal such as the domesticated horse doomed that culture to manual labor and almost certain losses when their foot soldiers faced mounted cavalry for the first time. Kudos to the author, big ideas,well thought out, and presented well <br />

B0000AUHPG|5.0|Once Upon a Time in the West is one of the finest Westerns ever, and a must see if you wish to familiarize yourself with the genre.<br /><br />Sergio Leone is most famous for his Man With No Name trilogy which brought Clint Eastwood to international fame.  His epic view of the American West is probably only matched by that of John Ford, but his films have a very distinct, mythical quality to them. Probably because Sergio Leone was not an American but an Italian.  It's more than a little odd that an Italian is responsible for some of the most indelible Western images of all time.  Then again Italy is famous for its artists.<br /><br />As with many Leone films the music score is done by none other than Ennio Morricone, and while the film would have been good without it, the music, as always, accentuates and compliments the film.  With Morricone the music becomes an unseen character that skillfully shapes the action.  Seek out all of his work, it's the product of genius.<br /><br />Charles Bronson as the harmonica wielding gunslinger is second only to Eastwood in the bad ass department.  But what makes this film so memorable is the villain played by Henry Fonda.  An obvious departure from most of, if not all of his other performances.  He's not just bad, he's evil, to the point where you boo and hiss (if only in your head) everytime he pops up on screen.<br /><br />If there's something that personifies the West Leone threw it in this movie, be it trains, six guns, horses, you name it, you'll probably find it here.<br /><br />The Western is an endangered genre that desperately needs help.  Movies like this show us why the Western deserves a reprieve from its inevitable extinciton, so watch this and any other Western that you can find.  Help the cause and tell a friend.<br /><br />P.S. \\"People scare better when they're dying.\\"

0767830555|5.0|Taxi Driver is an absolute masterpiece, showcasing the grittiness of New York City and the necessity of looking at  insanity in context.  In Martin Scorsese's breakneck film American audiences are treated to a brutal scrutiny of their own existence, whether it be the absurdity of party politics or the ever present danger of city life autonomy.<br /><br />The title character, one Travis Bickle, is played to disturbing perfection by Robert Deniro.  His gradual descent into self absorbed delusion results in one of film's most fascinating (and down right creepy) characters.  The conveyance of gentility coupled with madness has never been done better.<br /><br />Jodie Foster, as the damsel prostitute, gives a performance that borders on the impossible.  How an actress at that age could possibly play a hooker that convincingly either belies an eerily acute level of observation skills or a very poor upbringing.  I'd say her two Academy Awards probably eliminate the latter option.<br /><br />Taxi Driver has become an American fable, complete with heroes, villains, violence, and compassion.  A solid, complex film that defined urban drama and raised the bar for stark realism in film.  Besides, it inspired a presidential assassination attempt.  Obviously the film speaks to madmen, but it also echoes in the minds of the supposedly sane.<br /><br />One day Scorsese will be recognized with an Oscar, this film should have earned him that honor.  Too bad Hollywood doesn't give hindsight awards.

B0006L16N8|4.0|Coldplay's third studio album, \\"X&Y\\" could very well have been doomed from the beginning.  First, the band had the audacity to record a flawless masterpiece, \\"A Rush of Blood to the Head\\" on only their sophomore attempt.  It is equally unfair and inevitable that \\"X&Y\\" will be judged in light of the high standard set by its predecessor.  Then came the PR circus surrounding the release of this album - \\"Coldplay is In Line to become the Next U2\\", \\"Coldplay is Ready to Save Rock and Roll\\", \\"Coldplay Must Pull EMI Back into Profitability\\", \\"Coldplay doesn't Care at all about EMI's Profitability\\", and on and on.  All of these events served to create public preconceptions and set unnaturally critical expectations before anyone had heard a single note of its music.   <br /> <br />Well, now we have that music and the verdict is:  it's a very good album, nothing more and nothing less.  This shouldn't be a surprise to anyone who's heard the first single, \\"Speed of Sound\\", which is very similar to their earier hit \\"Clocks\\".  This album revisits Coldplay's signature sound and delivers 13 (yes, 13 - there is a hidden acoustic folk song at the end) strong examples of how good that sound can be.  So everyone can now take a breath, relax and enjoy it as simply the new Coldplay album.   <br /> <br />And make no mistake, this is a Coldplay album - if you like their sound, then you'll like this disc and vice versa.  The only real divergence from that formula comes in hints of 80s nostalgia.  For example, the piano melodies are now often augmented (or even replaced) by synth strings.  There are also throwbacks apparent in the rhythm section - Champion's drumming on \\"Square One\\" and \\"White Shadows\\" are reminiscent of vintage U2 and Big Country respectively.  And Guy Berryman finally gets the mix that his adept basswork has long deserved (i.e. you can hear him), sounding like a confident protege of a young Adam Clayton.   <br /> <br />Songwriting also owes allegiance to the 80s as well.\\"Square One\\" is probably the most \\"rock\\" track that they've ever released, and it sounds like the entire \\"Unforgettable Fire\\" album condensed into three minutes.  \\"Talk\\" contains elements of Kraftwerk melodies (they're even credited as co-writers), and \\"Low\\" was appropriately enough recorded along with Brian Eno, a longtime collaborator of David Bowie.   <br /> <br />There is a good balance between up-tempo numbers and ballads filled with Chris Martin's signature falsetto (\\"What If?\\", \\"Fix You\\").  This makes it a very easy album to listen to in its entirety.  It has the makings of another multi-platinum launched by several singles.  The strongest tracks include \\"Square One\\", \\"Fix You\\" and the very trippy/mellow Beatles-esque title track.   <br /> <br />The album does lose some points on unoriginality.  Contrast Coldplay's situation to that of U2 after \\"The Joshua Tree\\" - not content to simply release a sequel, Bono and company elected to tear their sound down and create something new, exciting and completely unexpected in \\"Achtung Baby\\".  Faced with a similar opportunity, Coldplay got cold feet - but they should have years head of them to craft a more mature creative course.  This inside-the-box thinking also makes the album a bit redundant by the end;  the strongest material is definitely showcased early on.   <br /> <br />So don't be weighed down by the hype machine - \\"X&Y\\" is a very good album but not Coldplay's greatest.  Still, it's highly recommended for fans of the band or anyone who appreciates well-crafted mellow alterna-rock.

it prevents the autorun program from opening and installing itself, and you can open up your favorite program to put it on your mp3 player (yes even itunes!)but if you have already let the stupid \\"mediamax\\" screen load, then you have to take the following step to remove the software from your computer (even if you didn't install it, you will know if this has happened to you because the playback will sound severely garbled) <br />open command prompt (start>programs>accessories>command prompt) and type the followind lines in (one at a time, pressing enter at the end): <br />net stop sbcphid <br />del %systemroot%\system32\drivers\sbcphid.sys <br />and you will be good to go! B000002X1O|5.0|True rating - an entire galaxy (Andromeda)  Some wonder what happened  to  the  principle players of the original Jefferson Airplane. The answer is that they kept getting better. During the time of this album's release, it was period  of the Jefferson Airplane -Jefferson Starship continuum when Jack and Jorma went off to form Hot Tuna while  Grace Slick and Paul Kantner had a child and for a time  made some of their best albums.    After Paul Kantner's successful solo project the 1970 science fiction rock epic \\"Blows Against the Empire\\" Kantner found himself in one of his most prolific writing periods. His writing style takes the form of the prophetic as he contemplates the meaning of the psychedelic  experience -his conclusion is that man's destiny lies in the stars.    Baron von Tollbooth and the Chrome Nun (the pet names bestowed  upon Slick and Kantner by their friend David Crosby) is a very mature  well produced  yet a daring  album that continues the Kantner space theme. Sharing the bill with Kantner and Slick is old folkie friend David Freiberg. They are joined  by a group that  reads like a who's who of the San Francisco  psychedelic scene: drummers John Barbata (formerly of CSN&Y) and Mickey Hart (loaned out from the Grateful Dead), Jorma Kaukonen,   legendary bassist Jack Casady, Violinist  Papa John Creech, the Pointer Sisters, David Crosby, Jack Traylor (a fellow psychedelic space rocker) and even Jerry Garcia himself. The entire album has a polished sound that has somewhat mystical theme layered on top of Kantner's visions  of life in space.    1) The Ballad of the Chrome Nun (Freiberg/Slick)  The song is classic Slick in its irreverence but is also optimistic. Although she may be poking fun at traditional religion  there is a spiritual nature to it. The song is well textured and Slick is in great voice.    2) Fat (Slick)  Backed up by the Pointer Sisters this song  has unmistakable religious almost Gospel music sound to it. Her lyric \\"so we all went through the wall\\" suggests such things as telepathy and telekinesis. And the fat  which she sings about seems to refer to excesses - most likely the excesses of the 60s. Yet in no way is this  group giving up their values but paring them down in preparation for a new world they envision. The repetition of Slick belting out the word \\"someday\\" is moving and hopeful. It is obvious  that they want  the psychedelic parade to continue  but  with a new focus.    3) Flowers of the Night (Traylor)  The song is sung by Kantner and in the lyric of this song Traylor lists political, intellectual and spiritual revolutionaries as  the song tells a story of change. The song  contains some beautiful guitar work.    4) Walkin' (Kantner/Slick)  The music is  bouncy with Creech on Violin in his characteristic style and Slick on the piano. The lyric is somewhat cryptic  but seems to offer a justification for the  chances taken in their  psychedelic rock and roll life style as well as  an invitation to the listener to live vicariously through their life, music and visions. Again like the rest of the songs on the album it is a very hopeful song.    5) Your Mind Has Left Your Body (Kantner)  This song seems to have to do with astroprojection and it was  written in the days when Kantner Leary and others were attempting to experiment with the phenomena. The \\"White Bear\\" some say refers to Augustus Owsley Stanley and the part of the chorus \\"riders of the rainbow\\" may come from the book title \\"Warriors of the Rainbow\\"-a book  about the mystical experiences of the American Indians. It is a beautiful visionary  and haunting.    6) Across the Board (Slick)  A beautiful but campy song and in true Grace Slick fashion Grace does her best vocally to spice things up. The  lyrics are more than a little suggestive but quite witty.    7) Harp Tree Lament (Freiberg/Hunter)  Co-written by Robert Hunter  Jerry Garcia's song writing partner the title refers to the Bible verse in which the children of Israel are goaded to sing for their captors. It is a somewhat slow down beat song but beautiful.    8) White Boy (Transcaucasian Airmachine Blues) (Kantner)  In this song  Kantner  sums  up  his work and states his thesis which began with the album Blows Against the Empire and which he continues to this very day. It clearly proposes idea that civilization is progressive  and our ultimate future is in outer space and further that we don't really belong here. It is a very thoughtful (and again hopeful) song. In 1973 when other rock artists were questioning the experience of the 60s and a feeling isolated Kantner gives  a more hopeful view.    9) Fishman (Slick)  The lyrics at first blush sound  pretty bizarre but it is actually a love song from Slick to Kantner. Slick's voice is powerful and  she really belts out the  lines.    10) Sketches of China (Kantner /Slick)  Sung by Kantner and Slick and accompanied by oriental sounding rock it tells a bizarre story in picture fragments. There seems to be some word play going on in the song between China the nation and China Kantner (Grace and Paul's daughter). It is ultimately a triumphant sounding song.    Baron von Tollbooth is one of the most beautiful and hopeful albums of the JA/JS opus. In it Kantner and Slick do their best to keep the spirit of the 60s going while focusing their eyes on the stars.    Highly recommended    Jim Connell    \\"Hallstatt Prince\\"
B0009HLDFU|5.0|This is the best Foo's album to date.  The opening 5 tracks on the rock CD blow you away and the accoustic tracks are sublime. <br />You must buy this CD it must surely be the best rock album of 2005!

0634049011|5.0|Tagliarino does something very few authors of guitar books have done - he puts the entire fretboard within reach of the guitar student.  About 99 percent of the guitar players I know panic when they get beyond the fourth fret.  But all of these players absolutely love the guitar and truly desire to learn the instrument - all the way to fret 12 and above.  They have all kinds of musical notes and guitar riffs in their heads, but can't reproduce them on the fretboard.  That is the worst kind of pain. <br /> <br />Fortunately, Tagliarino's method is the \\"wonder drug\\" that takes the mystique out of the guitar fretboard and makes it all come together.  Please be advised however, that getting this book doesn't reduce the necessity of practice. What students should experience is an increased desire to practice more! My advice to any guitar player, or instructor for that matter - get this book and the boxed set of Fretboard Logic (with DVD) by Edwards - and get to work!  Within six months: you, your friends, your students, your teachers - eveyone - will be absolutely amazed at your increased level of knowledge.  Take the plunge and buy this book! You won't regret your investment!

B0000026VZ|4.0|Another rock group whose big splash was in the 80's was Toto, who peaked at having their album Toto IV and single \\"Rosanna\\" winning Grammies for 1982.  That worthy tune, which spent 5 weeks at #2, being kept from the top spot by first the Human League and then Survivor, sported the characteristic sizzle of Steve Lukather's rock guitar, smooth and soaring vocals by Bobby Kimball, and a horn section for additional flourish as well as some great keyboard work by David Paitch and Steve Porcaro.  Oh, and Rosanna referred to Lukather's then-girlfriend, actress Rosanna Arquette.  Two other hits from that album included the Top 5 \\"Africa\\" with its prominent synth keyboards and the #10 ballad \\"I Won't Hold You Back\\" with its orchestral backing.<br /><br />They began with \\"Hold The Line\\" from their eponymous 1979 debut, a #5 hit and an introduction to their signature rock sound, specifically Lukather's guitar.  \\"Georgy Porgy\\" veers more towards adult contemporary with its laid back but brisk morning pop aura, intercut with lines from the old nursery rhyme.<br /><br />The video for the heartbreak song \\"I'll Be Over You\\" was my first exposure to Toto, though I had heard their music on David Lynch's adaptation of Dune.  A line that rang true with me October 2004 was \\"as soon as my heart stops breaking/and disappears/as soon as forever is through/I'll be over you.\\"  This song along with \\"Rosanna\\" are my two favourite Toto songs here.  Michael McDonald can be heard giving backing vocal assistance in the chorus.  This single from their album Fahrenheit, features the debut of new lead singer Joseph Williams, son of John Williams of the Boston Pops.<br /><br />For The Seventh One, Joseph Williams, son of John Williams of the Boston Pops, took the helm as lead singer.  \\"Stop Loving You\\" combined some of elements of their earlier style, horns, electric guitarwork and was snazzy pop/rock.  \\"Pamela,\\" their last Top 40 hit (#22) lacked the oomph of their earlier singles.  Rather, it has watered down elements of \\"99\\", the #28 song from their second album Hydra. B00092ZMDY|5.0|Just got finished watching this, and I came away once again very impressed with the pure muscianship and attention to production. These guys are known perfectionists and it shows. Some say their live performances sound too much like the records, but on this one they spice it up a little more than on Hell Freezes Over, though there aren't many cool acoustic ones like on that DVD. This one is less stiff than HFO too.  Don Felder is missing on this one (out of the band since '01), but the guy filling in does a OK job, though it's just not the same on Hotel California. I thought the best performance was Walsh's Funk #49. It demands to be rocked LOUD in DTS. As with HFO, the recording quality is superb with DTS as the only surround option (just as HFO & Henley's DVD). The Eagles do this as DTS is better than Dolby as it uses less compression, and they can increase the video resolution when the Dolby track is left off.  In fact, I think this DVD sets the standard in sound quality for live mixes.  I have the Hotel California DVD-Audio, and the mix and realism sounds better here due to more available tracks to mix from and it utilizes higher resolution digital recording (though nothing can touch the resolution on a DVD-Audio or SACD).  Overall, there's more songs, and it's more of a rockin' set than HFO. Frey & Schmit look great while Henley, and especially Walsh, are starting to show their age (was that Hermes pajama bottoms Walsh was wearing?). Though Walsh's voice sounds the freshest. If you like great music, buy this. If you have a great sound system, buy this, as it will really show it off and make you glad you spent the big bucks.  As a last note, the Eagles share my passion for wine.  When their manager, Irving Azoff, shared some Lafite Rothschild with them in 1974, they began putting in their tour contracts that first growth Bordeaux would be in their dressing rooms.  Some may say that this is a primadona request, but I can't think of a better perk.
